div.p: RB MSS 439c, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne.

Only since yesterday, dear Mr Guilfoyle, I am in possession of your kind letter of the 8th of May.
Letter not found. I hope you are quite recovered from your illness. I am myself very much suffering from an obstinate attack of bronchitis. I have of late given up sending plants in pots horizontally & always cover the ball with calico now.

Whenever you go to San Francisco, let me know it, so that the letters of introduction may be of recent date. One of my influencial friends there is Dr Hermann Behr, a physician in active practice and of extensive phytologic knowledge, altho' he devotes his few recreation hours now to the study of Lepidoptera; and you could make him doubly a friend, if you timely put up for him any butterfly, that may fall into your hand, for his magnificent cabinet, in which the Australian species are hitherto but very scantily represented.
I am glad you hold out a prospect for obtaining Museum plants from the southern parts of N.S.W. Much would be learnt by these plants in reference to their local & general distribution

I regret to confess, that I have not yet carefully examined those of your ferns, which our friend Mr W. Woolls so kindly sent to me. It is quite a charity to me, to expect not too much extrawork from me during the planting season. —

The specimen of Polypodium from Aneitum, as you surmised is P. Horsfieldii R.Br., for which however there is an older name = P. dipteris Blume. [...]
